Veggie spring rolls are some of the best I've ever had though. Also the veggie fried rice is great. All the girls who work there are really sweet and the service is pretty quick. Worth a visit if you're in the haight
author: Caitlin S.

description:
LYCHEE SWEET N SOUR PORK!!!

This place was pretty delicious. I enjoyed my entree very much (see above) and the dude's entree was pretty good too (scarlet duck curry something something).

Also, the price is right! Cheap cheap for good good.

My only gripes, which I take off one star for, is the service was kinda slow. Took their time taking our order, and bringing the check. And, my pineapple vodka lemonade? I think there was no vodka.

But, yeah. LYCHEE SWEET N SOUR PORK!!!!
author: Rachel H.

description: Party of four ordered many dishes - even veg - and each was spot on. Fresh, spicy, light. Friendly staff, excellent food. Recommended!
author: Mark C.

description:
The Chicken Panang Curry had a tingle your tongue hotness and had  a cream curry sweetness.  Though, the chicken was dry and the prawns (add $2 extra) was nothing special.  The dish also came with julienne red and green bell peppers, which were crisp and fresh.

The service needs some work, like the waiter dropping off the menu on my dinner plate.  And not asking me for a drink before taking my order.  And not clearing the table before dropping off the check.  I'm a stickler for observation, when I'm the only customer at a restaurant.

Otherwise, the food was good.  The ambience is nice (candles on the table, art on the walls).  And I saw at least three people walking by, outside, with a slice of pizza from Escape From New York Pizza.  Must try that next time!
author: Sam T.

description:
parking is difficult so if you like to walk on haight you can park away and walk here.

i decided to just try the fried chicken and pineapple fried rice.  my friend had the catfish.

i loved it.  it was full of flavor well prepared. the chicken was chicken katsu.  the fried rice had cashew, raisins, pineapple, and i forget.  it was really tasty.  it just wasn't huge or really big enough for me.  hence the 3 stars.  if it was just a little bit more i'd give it a 4.

my friend had the catfish. same thing. kind of decent size portion but for hungry people its just a little too small.  BUT the catfish had wondeful flavor, was cooked perfectly.  my friend was worried it might be sea catfish so its a bit salty and has that ocean fishy taste, but this was fresh water catfish which made it taste nice and tenderly sweet.  with the sauce they gave.  which also had steamed rice.
author: Bing D.

description:
I decided to come here on my work break one day since my manager wouldn't shut up about how good it was.  I asked them how long the wait would be to take some tofu and vegetables to go, and then told me 15 minutes.

So I waited there for 25 minutes, paid for my meal, then asked for a side of oyster sauce and then wanted to charge me $1.50.  I left really upset because I wasted precious break time on waiting and extra 10 minutes.

I was really disappointed with my food, I felt like it was more Chinese food than Thai.  The vegetables weren't cooked that well, the tofu was almost nonexistent, and there was no flavored sauce or anything.

I suppose I gave it two stars because it's a lot cheaper than most things on Haight Street, but I definitely will not be reordering from here.
author: Dylan C.

description:
Good noodle dishes, just the right amount of spice.
The kicker are the desserts though: ask about the Mango ice cream or fried banana plate.
Seriously, they love talking about the mango though.
Service may be a little slow, but it's worth the wait, unless you're absolutely starving. I did enjoy the Thai Iced Tea though...
author: Jessica P.

description: I really hate this neighborhood (pardon that lame, overused pun, but my loathing is genuine); however, I'll give due praise for the quaint little restaurant, its friendly service and beef pad kee mao. Enough to rave endlessly and come back craving more? Not really. But maybe in the future...
author: Chase S. K.

description:
This is really a 3 and 1/2 (again tell Yelp we need 1/2 rating here) 

I popped into this place with my fellow vegan foodie off the 71 bus line. Pretty hungry and looking for a new Thai place, the menu offered a myriad of seafood, meat and vegetarian/vegan options (which is rare because most Thai places slap tofu instead of meat and think it's vegetarian. BEWARE, almost all Thai entrees have fish sauce, so make sure the menu is designated vegetarian versus tofu as a meat option).

After contemplating the abundance of veggie options, I decided on a classic yellow curry. This is a very typical dish in Thai cooking, but that does not mean that every yellow curry you try will be good. The hook-line and sinker to this dish was the unexpected addition of winter squash (an orange, pumpkin-like sweet squash that plays very well with the spicy curry and sweet coconut milk).  This dish was not only impressive to my Thai-food-loving taste buds, but also was satisfying to my 1/2 Thai fellow vegan foodie. 

She ordered some spicy noodle dish... I can't remember the name, but I remember the dish. It was true to the spicy verses that Thai food can sing so well. Large flat noodles with lots of stir fried veggies with a sweet, brown soy based sauce.  

With an unsweetened (sorry non-milk drinkers/ lac-tards no soy here) Thai iced tea and a hot tea, the lunch that was expected to be a so-so meal turned out to be a curry-colored diamond in the rough. 

A caution to those of your to choose to fulfill your Thai food cravings, this little gem is closed on Tuesdays (boo, right?) and, although this may seem minor, they don't have tamarind candies.  SL has become our new little Thai spot :)

cheers, 
the vegan foodies (written by Tara, the Karim in Karimaford and admittedly the high strung half of the vegan.foodie.team )
author: Maria W.

description:
One of the best thai restaurants in the City and I've been exposed to many thanks to my bf's (and his family's home cookin') years of experience eating in Thailand, Wat Thai and Thai Town in So Cal. The portions were generous (prices, very reasonable) and we were waited on, not had to wait a bit to get service on a Sunday afternoon. 

We both had the lunch specials - Chicken with Mango + Catfish with Ginger, Bell Peppers and Crisp Thai Basil - a great twist to the usual and was served with a heaping scoop of rice and a "real" mixed green salad with hearty greens rather than the dreaded butter lettuce.

And our yardstick, Thai Iced Tea had an excellent ratio of tea, sugar and cream. My only complaint though was the ice was not crushed or shaved (the best kind!) and instead came in the mundane cube form. But I will return!
author: Charm N.

description:
Randomly walked in here when my counterpart and I were both feeling pretty low.  About to have a night on the town and both of us were sick!  We needed something soothing and comforting to eat.  Decided some warm hot & sour soup would do us good.

Immediately seated by a strange host, he jumped the gun a lot and talked over us while we were ordering.  Almost like he was in a hurry.  But whatever, we ordered our drinks and reviewed the menu.  Everything was priced decently and looked yummy.  We both ended up with hot & sour soup with chicken, order of rice, some spring rolls, and he got the mahi mahi.

The  food came out fast and in an order I liked.  Soup first, then spring rolls, then the main dish.  By the time the fish came out I was stuffed.  The soup was delicious and the spring rolls crispy. (I LOVE crispy rolls!)

He gave us our check pretty fast and we were on our way.  Probably could have been closer to a 5 star review had the service been a little nicer.
author: Mary R.

description: This place is legit.  It has outstanding food.  Its perfect when you are out shopping in the haight and you decide to get a bite to eat.  You must have Thai at this place you won't be disappointed.
author: Chris J.

description: I ordered the Green Curry Rice Plate (take out) from Siam yesterday. The curry was flavorful and the portion size was appropriate for the price. Can't really add anything about the dining experience at the place but looked nice enough. Also found out while ordering over the phone that you can also order online FYI. Good local spot around the corner from me. It's nice to have 2 good Thai places so close to my apartment (Ploy II across the street).
author: Todd A.

description:
The freshest Thai food in town!  My favorite dishes are the Golden Veggie Curry, Spicy Thai Basil Eggplant, Coconut Veggie Soup.  The veggies are so fresh and are cooked to perfection.  

Great service and affordable- you will not be dissappointed!
author: Marn E.

description: I find it difficult to break away from my normal order of Pad Thai. But Siam Lotus had a wonderful array of lunch specials that made me want to break with the norm. Everything sounded great. It was a tough call. I wanted curry. I really really wanted curry. But the crispy noodle curry caught my eye. I am a bit spoiled having eaten curry every day for over a month while traveling in Thailand, I was so very pleasantly surprised at how good this curry was. A yellow curry with crispy noodles piled on top of beef (or chicken, shrimp or tofu) and soft noodles (no rice). It was a huge bowl of yummyness! And what does that sign say? "$2 drafts ALL DAY EVERY DAY" What???? And then to top it all off, it's in the wonderful people watching district of the Haight. I could go back here every day and try something different.
author: Jay B.

description: Good prices. Good curry and pad see ew. Other food was okay. we were in a big group and it was not too bad a price for the amount of food we had. Didn't look at the menu since we were eating family style. I'm sure the prices were fine individually.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
I'm feeling lazy so I'm going to be concise.

Positives: Good Thai food, nice staff, cute Thai themed decor, reasonable prices.

Negatives: Parking sucks at Haight, but if you're from around here, you know that. You'd also know that there may be bums around and they WILL have the audacity to ask you for money so they can score some drugs. :P
author: Bekki J.

description:
Oh no- they're closed on Tuesdays! (Today is Tuesday, blah!)
Average cost, yummy thai :) 

This dish was SO FABULOUS!!! 

30. Grilled Lemongrass Chicken (gai-yang) Tasty thai grilled chicken marinated with lemon grass, coconut milk, coriander and thai herbs served with spicy pineapple sauce.

It is only the chicken though- no veggies or liquidy sauce. Mmmm, so tasty! 
Not greasy or anything either. 

Red Curry with Beef and Tom Kha Gai were basic, average. I think Red Curry usually tastes better with chicken or pork because the white meat soaks in more of the curry than beef does. 

No comments about service because we got take-out, but the servers there were all really nice when we picked up the food.
author: Amy J.

description: I think this is the best Thai food we've every had!  The coconut pad thai was awesome and the Thai basil with mango was amazing!!!  Everything tasted very fresh!  The staff is super friendly, too!
author: Khani Z.

description:
This is the best Thai restaurant in the neighborhood, and the best Thai food I've had in a long time.  Their menu offers more than the standards and their specials are always exciting.  I take great pleasure in their seafood.  I find that many Thai restaurants cook the hell out of their prawns, but not Siam Lotus.  They take care with their dishes.

The service is not so reliable.  They don't do big groups too well.
author: Lulu B.

description:
Simple place - fantastic food.  I had the green curry with chicken, and it was really amazing.  The eggplant was to DIE for!

Also inexpensive.
author: Kevin D.

description:
This is one of the best thai places I have found since I moved to the Bay Area in 2001. The service is always really good and the food is.... great *sigh*. They have a big menu with all the traditional Thai dishes (curries, pad thai, etc) and a lot of interesting fusion items. Every time I have eaten here I have tried different things from their menu, and I have never been disappointed. The lamb curry was especially memorable...
My only complaint is that it wouldn't hurt if they kicked up the spice levels a couple of notches. If it weren't for that, I would give Siam Lotus Thai 5 stars.
author: Daniela A.

description:
As a little warning, I ate here while somewhat intoxicated, last minute before seeing a movie at the Red Vic. I live on the other end of the upper Haight and infrequently make it past Best of Thai when I am in search of Thai goodness. I think after my most recent dining experience here, I may be pulled down here to enjoy the food again. 

I would say this place has food with good flavor, great variety and a few unique additions like the Thai Taco. My palette may have been a little off, but I did find both the Thai Taco and the Pad See Ew to be a bit on the sweet and salty side. Perhaps they add something to make Americans think 'damn this is good' or maybe I am just crazy. I will give it another try or two.
author: Alicia J.

description:
In any other city, outside of NYC, this would a top notch Thai place.

In SF, it is average. It is a good place and a good time for a large group.
author: Rahul T.

description: As a former native who still loves the Haight/Ashbury District, this thai restaurant is a must-stop for lunch. Since we were shopping in the area, we needed to get lunch in that area; our choices were between the pizza joint and this thai restaurant. The menu out front was intriguing. So we chose this place. The inside of the restaurant looked nice too. For the appetizer, we got the spring rolls, which had a good mix of chicken, vegetables, and thin clear noodles. Yummy. We got the entree plates, as the lunch specials do not come with rice. My husband got the yellow curry dish with chicken and I got the spicy eggplant with chicken. The presentation was very nice. My husband cannot do spicy but found that it was seasoned with the right amount of  spice. He said it had a bit of zing. I tried it; it was excellent---it reminded me of our good thai restaurants back home in LV, Lotus of Siam in the Commercial Center and Mix Zone Cafe at Charleston/Rancho. My dish was spicy, just the way I like it. There was a lot of food;a  good mix of chicken, vegetables and basil. I don't think that I finished it; good sized portions. (Maybe if we didn't have the Spring Rolls.) We were glad we came her for lunch; we will definitely have to stop by again, the next time. We were seated at the window (pictured below). Soon after, the lunch crowd started to come in. There were a couple To-Go orders. Also noticed the "Yelp" stickers all over the front windows. I couldn't wait to post my review.
author: Margret C.

description: Wow, the flavors of the food are amazing!  This place is family-owned and run.  They really take pride in their business, their food, and the service they provide to their customers.  The owner, a wonderful Thai woman, tells me they have been open since 1999.  It is obvious why they are still in business - definitely recommended!
author: J R.

description:
I am not a Thai aficionado by any means. The food was good, but service was soo slow. We were the first table there, a ratio of 2 adults and 2 toddlers to like 4 servers.

Shrimp Spring Rolls could have  been  a little fresher, the veggie ones were great though. Lemon grass chicken was yummy as was the chicken satay (i love a good peanut sauce).
author: allison s.

description:
*****BEST LARB ON HAIGHT.*****


*(but called 'lap gai', don't know why)
I ate here the first week I moved to California, so it has a special nostalgic place in my cold little heart.

Highlights:
Kha Gai, Po-Tak, Phad-Phrik Sot, Spicy Basil Eggplant, Panang & Green curries. oh! And the cucumber salad it refreshing.
And they'll make everything vegetarian if you ask nicely.
I also had a delicious salmon param with spinach once, it was a special and it was delicious. Bring that back.
The waitstaff is always polite. They are on time with orders.
I only dock a star because they don't deliver and I am not walking when I feel lazy.
author: Claire S.

description:
I had a hanker for a hunk of Thai,  in the Ha-iggit. We set out for Ploy II but oops, closed on Mondays, shoulda called first, my bad. Over to that thing across the street, which turned out to be Siam Lotus. Wife sez "it's decent..."

Okay so it's decent. Decor is a bit spare, menu options were enticing, the food was pretty darn good, service was OK. A solid 4/5 across the board: decent, but not great. I ordered a "Han Solo" from the drinks menu and it was by no means a rockstar scoundrel drink from Star Wars. More like a lame drink from Ice Pirates. Yawn.

Ways they could be better: more swanky decor (or more funky decor, _do_somefin'_ with the place), snappier service, put some sauces and flowers on the tables, get some groovy tunes going, and put a handful of crazy things on the menu - crazy fusion, or deep cuts from real Thai cuisine that normal Thai restaurants in the USA are afraid to serve, whatever, just reward the adventurous weirdos who order the stuff. And revamp that drink menu, I know they're making do without a liquor license but they can be creative and come up with some fun drinks that people won't be disappointed by.
author: Jamie F.

description:
I had an overall good lunch experience at this place but overall food quality was only part of the reason. The pace of the meal was perfect, apps came when they should, soup when it should and meals when they should. Presentation was five stars for sure and big points for some unique thai dishes on the menu (most thai spots in the city may as well share the same menu).

Sad truth was that the curry dishes we got were sub-excellent which was unexpected all else considered. The price point was right though, especially for a great lunch experience before the red vic, and I would like to return and try a few more dishes. 

The golden triangles were unique and excellent although more like a samosa than thai. Stay away from the chicken coconut soup.
author: M L.

description:
Really good food all around. Seemed fairly small inside, but we didn't have to wait for a table during dinner-time-ish on a weekday. Relatively inexpensive, I thought, though not necessarily what I would classify as "cheap".

There were four in my group, and we were all pleased with the food. The service was pretty good, and fast. I had the crispy chicken with pineapple fried rice, and everything about it was fantastic. I also enjoyed the menu more than a typical Thai place, though I can't really explicate why. I think it just seemed like there was a bigger variety and a lot of unique dishes, rather than just the basic curries and pad-somethings.
author: Derek S.

description:
Whether it be fair or not, I don't think that mediocre Thai restaurants deserve patronage.  There are just too many good places to choose from in a city like San Francisco.  I would lump Siam Lotus into that category of "mediocre."  There was nothing wrong with the service or food, but there was nothing that stood out.  The food soup was flavorful, the masamun was average, and the pad si eww was bland.  

I'll give it another chance because as we were walking out, we saw the waitresses eating their dinners and both plates looked delicious.  One was eating the grilled lemongrass chicken & spinach noodles while the other was eating a dish with some massive prawns.

I'm not ready to give up on Siam Lotus just yet, but unless my next experience there is better, they've lost me as a customer.  There are just too many places that have food with taste and treat make you feel like your business if important to settle for mediocre.
author: Lucius M.

description: We went there on a Monday afternoon and I ordered a dish that I am trying to remember because it was really good. It had lamb and a coconut curry saffron sauce that was amazing..I looked at the online menu and can not find it though. I have been thinking about that dish for weeks now it was yummy!!!!
author: Melissa L.

description: Best Thai food in the neighborhood - absolutely fantastic.  Only reason it isn't getting 5 stars from me is that they don't deliver...and on a rainy, dreary Sunday I would choose a place that doesn't require any effort.  Try the crispy pineapple fried rice - heaven.
author: Betsy C.

description:
I do not like this place. The service is bad and the food is not tasty.
The sign says "Please wait to be seated" We waited, then a waitress came by saying do you need a seat? We said, yes. She walked away into the kitchen and never came back. Oh yeah there were a lot of open table. So we sat down for about 5 minutes. I asked my friend if she wanted to leave. She said she does not care. We were about to leave then another waitress came and seated us. 
We ordered the tacos that they are "known" for and the seafood noodle soup dish.
The tacos are good, but it was way to sweet to have it as a starter. It was more like a dessert.
The seafood noodle soup tasted like water.
I asked the waitress for some hot sauce, she said "okay"
She never brought me the hot sauce.

Bad food. Bad service. Ugly arrangement of tables.
Would NOT come back here again.

For great Thai food try Thai Time and Tawan in the Richmond.
author: Chatree T.

description: Good prices and cheap beer. Nice to see in the Haight. I like the Chicken Eggplant with Basil, and while it may not have the most "authentic" atmosphere and menu as other places in SF I leave with my belly full of good food. No complaints!
author: Travis H.

description:
My husband and I have eaten here 3 times (just about every time we've been on Haight Street) and we've enjoyed it every time. My favorite dish is the peach curry with prawns, but it's only offered in the spring (good for using seasonal ingredients, bad because I CRAVE it year round). 
There are several favorable reviews about their Thai tacos, but we found them too sweet, especially with the cucumbers and mirin they serve as a condiment. I'd have preferred some fish sauce and sriracha. 
The tom kha (chicken coconut milk) soup is always amazing--it's one of my favorite dishes of all time, and they do it right. 
The "cocktails" are kind of fun--since they don't have a full bar, don't expect real vodka or rum in any of them, but they're sweet and easy-drinking.
If you have any room for dessert, the mango with black sticky rice is heavenly.
author: Courtney K.

description: A real find.  Family run, fresh food, changing menu and very consistent.  Servers are great.  Love the mango salmon curry in particular.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
This place is pretty good, a step up from Best of Thai Noodle.

I've only had the green curry lunch, it was good.
I'm anxious to try more.
author: Chili B.

description:
Order everything on the menu that includes mango:  spicy mango basil chicken, mango chicken jungle curry, mango with sticky rice.  The pad thai was pretty tasty and Chicken Kra Pro (sp?) is super crispy.  The spicy eggplant is my new favorite.

You will not be disappointed ... with the food, anyway.  Service is iffy, but that's standard in the Haight.  It's a bit pricey, which is also standard for the Haight.  I've been able to blow it off based on the overall quality of the food, which is NOT standard in the Haight.
author: T T.

description:
Thanks yelp!  Read the reviews here and decided to stop by while in SF for the weekend.

It was great!  The pineapple juice was so good here, I got my sister hooked on the stuff.  The food itself was fantastic.  It was a good time, and we seemed to have beaten the lunchtime rush.  Didn't hurt that we were seated beside some awesome people mathematically calculating what they should order to make everyone happy for 20 minutes.

Would definitely come back if I'm ever on the left coast again.
author: Wren R.

description: I traveled to Thailand last year, not to mention I'm a snob about what I consume. I am pleased to say that this is authentic Thai food that is delicious! It's not upscale and I love that it isn't. It is some real authentic Thai cooking. I tried the spicy chicken lemongrass soup, and it was so zesty with ginger. If you're sick order a bowl of that. It'll give you a boost. The pad thai was good, the satay chicken was good. The service was great! Thank you. The servers were so attentive and welcoming. Only positive things to say.
author: Miss P.

description:
This was an unexpected find in the haight ashbury neighborhood.  I went with a large group and tried many dishes.  Most are quite decent.  The standouts are:

coconut pad thai - had this for the first time.  It's pad thai kicked up a notch with coconut milk infused in the dish.  It's probably very bad for you in a tasty way.

hot and sour coconut soup - came in individual bowls filled with chicken and mushroom
author: Edda S.

description:
A friend and I ran into this after yet another spacy stroll on a Sunday afternoon on Haight Street.  Went in to get a quick snack and we weren't disappointed!

Between the two of us we ordered the Lap Tao Hu..which  was fried tofu (not oily at all) tossed in some sort of a green/red chili, mint leaves and lime vinaigrette sauce. Absolutely delicious!!!

Also had the spring rolls which were decent. All stars for the tofu! Warning: if you want chinese tea, specify if not chances are the waiter will get you heated thai tea..yuck not a personal favorite.

Will definitely go back to try the jumbo prawns in the coconut curry clay pot!
author: sri b.

description:
Wow, I'm surprised at the 1 and 2 star ratings Siam has gotten. Ever since I had lunch here a year ago, I ADORE place! I have yet to have had anything beyond delicious and lemme tell you, as a spice addict:

THEY DO NOT PLAY WITH THEIR SPICE LEVELS! you tell them spicy and you'll be breathing fire when you walk out. 

Their pad see ewe is one of the more flavorful ones out of all the Thai places I frequent and their quirky Thai Tacos...whoever came up with that was a genius!

Oh and just let me say that for the Saturday after my birthday this past September it was an hour and a half wait up the street at Cha Cha Cha's for a solid 12 people...10 minutes at Siam. 

Tell me any other restaurant that can do that.
author: Daneca V.

description: I Love this retaurant - not only for eating in, but take out.  The food is exemplary and the staff are all super nice.  I love their Param Beef, Chicken or Park dish with rice.  I could literally live on this without a problem.  Their peanut sauce is fabulous. The atmosphere of this small restaurant is peaceful, clean and classy.  No trip to the Haight would be complete without lunch or dinner at this fine establishment!
author: Norah M.

description: This is an easy one. Great food (non-greasy, yet tasty), great price ($8-$13 for most items), great service (food ready within 8 minutes of ordering). What more do you want?
author: Morin O.

description: Small little place with delicious food and an earnest staff
author: Alyxandra D.

description: Eh, nothing bad, but overall just kinda average Thai food.  You can do way better across the street at Ploy II (assuming it's not a Tuesday).
author: Mark A.

description:
Oh Siam Lotus, how tasty you are.  If only you weren't in the Haight I would eat at you more often!

Even though I only make it here a couple of times a year the adorable waiter always remembers me and treats me like an old friend.

They have this amazing dish with tempura coconut shrimp served on salad with this yummy tangy honey mustard sort of dressing.  Its so good that my husband who hates salad dressing likes it anyway, and we have tried to replicate the dish at home with varying results.

They have brown rice which is so much healthier and very rare in your typical thai joint.  In any case, I think they are significantly better than the average thai place in SF but with reasonable average prices.
author: Deniz T.

description:
Siam Lotus is my spot! 
What kicks ass? Everything. 

All the curries are delicious, and the appetizers always kill.

Tasty, delicious, cheap, good atmosphere.
author: Amy M.

description: The Tom Yum is excellent (sweet and spicy, with a kick), and so is the service and ambiance.  Great place to stop in for a quick bite in between all the stores on Haight!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Best happy hour ever: $2 pints of good beer (we're talkin Fat Tire and Anchor Steam). When is this happy hour, might you ask? All day, every day. 

The food's good too, they have some interesting curries along with the more traditional Thai fare. But honestly, does it even matter?
author: Em G.

description: Yum. Solid Thai food and a good atmosphere.
author: Amy S.

description:
If there is one thing reliable about Thai restaurants, its the hot Thai waitresses.  As much as I like Thai food, the hot imports are what truly keep me coming back for seconds or ordering an unnecessary  dessert.  For those men who have been plagued with the yellow fever like myself, this may not be restaurant for you.

Yes they do have A Thai waitress, but she is appealing as the gold styrofoam Thai Buddhas.  Fortunately, the food makes up for the inadequacies of service aesthetics.  They have some tasty appetizers like the Thai tacos or a rice side dish like the pineapple fried rice that will party all the way down your GI tract.  

One more perk, that conciliates my greatest pet peeve of Asian restaurants--they accept credit cards.  OMG, I never like to say that silly valley girl phrase, but I will degenerate myself for something as tremendous as credit accepted in a Thai restaurant.
author: John P.

description:
My boyfriend and I go there a lot for lunch special.  We love this place alot!  I love their red veg curry with tofu, it's the best red curry I've ever had!  The gay waiter is awesome too; his service is great, and is the nicest waiter ever!

Their eggplant dish is also good.  Though the price is bit higher than other thai restaurants in downtown SF, I still love their red curry so much, so I go there alot. 

so the nice gay waiter and red curry make me go back.

they are the best.
author: moshi m.

description: Tasty Thai treasure on Haight. Mango Thai Basil was great. Fast, friendly service.
author: michael p.

description: I really love the thai fried rice. Love it. Crave it all the time. Even when I've just finished eating it. (Un?)Fortunately, Siam Lotus is a block from my house. It's my go-to takeout place, and on special occasions, I even eat in the restaurant. I know, I'm adventurous. The service is fast (sometimes faster to eat there than to get takeout? Go figure). I've even bought fried rice here to sneak into the Red Vic. Some of the waitstaff are a little clueless, but they're sweet and attentive. Last Friday, my friend got some bad tofu. That was sad. But I'll go back. I'll go anywhere for that fried rice. Oh, there seem to be a lot of awkward first dates that happen in this restaurant. If Yelp had an option for me to recommend this place for awkward first dates, I'd check that box. Oh, one more thing: It's always happy hour. Bizarre. But awesome.
author: Lara C.

description: Service was good but I felt that the food was a notch down from mediocre.  I was hoping to break myself of the idea that there were no good restaurants in this area too.  No such luck.
author: joe b.

description: Very very very good Thai!  Superb beer specials, extensive menu and lunch was amazingly delicious.  I've never seen jumbo prawns that big!  Sake selection was a nice bonus and the location was perfect.
author: Mark T.

description: Clean place on Haight, very good food, very reasonably priced. Pretty quick too, just tough parking near Haight.
author: Ian K.

description:
I found this place 7 years ago and it is still one of my most frequented food haunts in the City. I hate to pull this card BUT, I have been to Thailand, and Siam Lotus serves the real thing. The food is very good, decent portions and affordable. The ambiance is down to earth, none of those silly costumes and distasteful gold Thai decor so often intrusive in Thai restaurants. The background music usually consists of jazz or some easy electronic beats. The staff, some of which have been there since I have started patroning, is attentive if you need them and  never annoying or in your face for tips. They leave you alone with your food. This place is about the food, not about the service, or the decor. Go for the food.

Update: Recently went and was very disturbed by the new tunes selection. BAD BAD pop tunes, Mariah Carey and some others, and too loud to ignore too. PLEASE please bring back the hip music! Please?
author: Miranda B.

description:
In a sea of fish sauce infused thai food, Siam Lotus has found a delicate balance of flavor without the funk.  I love the consistently delicious curries, noodle dishes, brown rice and abundance of vegetables.  The thai iced tea is robust and refreshing, plus they will make your dish without tofu if you are concerned with genetically modified soy products living and breeding in your belly.  

Last but not least they have they have good service for a casual style dining restaurant (especially if you are a regular).  An overall a great value despite the few cheapsters reviewing here!

As with most take out places though there is always the risk of getting sick from the food.  Lets be realistic 3 stars is about right.
author: Fernando F.

description: Really liked the mint beef salad, very good flavours. All of our feed was good, not greasy, not crazy big portions. Kid-friendly bright informal place. Substantially better than the food we had from Bangkok 900 on Stanyan. Friendly service. Our two and five year old boys wolfed down the food. We will come back, I'm sure.
author: Angus H.

description: Their food is excellent.  The atmosphere isn't that great, if you're looking for that kind of a thing.  Ploy across the street is cuter on the inside, but the food at Siam Lotus blows Ploy out of the water.  Also, there's a better selection of beer.  If they have the soft-shell crab special going, it is a MUST.  I highly recommend this place.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Finally, I found a good Thai in the city!

I had my Basil Chicken extra spicy and it was soooooo delicious. My friend's Chicken w Pineapple was very good too. 

Good space (i.e., privacy), airy, clean and good service!
author: Amy C.

description: This place had the best and cheapest Thai food I've ever had. Huge portions! there are a couple of Thai restaurants in the area but this has the best quality and you'll have the most left overs from here! The Roast Duck Fried Rice is awesome. Don't waste your time at ploy 2, Bangkok 500 or best of Thai
author: Alexandra D.

description: Great dinner spot my friend took me to last night. The Giesen Riesling was really nice to see on the menu, and everything was delicious. We started with a beef appetizer (yum, awesome dipping sauce) and the fried tofu (not my bag so much). I had the pawns in peach curry, which was absolutely awesome, choochee sauce with fresh peaches! Sticky rice is always good :) My friend had the lemongrass chicken, which looked really good too. The service was decent, but it was pretty crowded so perhaps that made it harder to catch a waiter at times. Overall, excellent dinner spot!
author: Irene F.

description:
Am a bio grad student at SFSU and had just spent the night in my lab cramming for my genetics exam. I took that genetics test and as soon as it was over (like at 6) my friend and I were super tired and he was like, am going home in need to sleep! am like okay me too, as soon as i said that am like noooo am hangry! am going to "reward" myself with the biggest burrito from el farolito, but wait, what could be better than that? OMG SIAM LOTUS's GREEN CURRY!!!! Here is my ode to the green curry from Siam lotus: I love that curry so much i would marry it and have its curry babies. I will also denounce my Mexican citizenship and officially become a Siam lotus national, Once you have that green curry you will never go back to that overrated marnee thai shit, moreover, i am convinced that the little thai waitresses lace that shit with crack, cause' how else u explain such devotion. 
Okay back to the story, I was soooo exhausted but i was on a mission, I decided to make the trip all the way to height street to have a taste of that succulent, chicken green curry, and so i did. It took me about 1.5 hours to get there, but at the end oh i was soooo worth it. The first spoonful of that curry was almost orgasmic, the "spicyness" was perfect, and yes I eat that big boy with a SPOON! cause i like to take spoonfuls of that green curry, and may i dare to say i eat it without taking a bite out of the rice! I love that curry so much I would just drink it, as soon as i started eating it my problems melted away and I forgot all about that effed up "write the karyotype of a person with translocation on the 18 chromosome" question. I dont understand the reviews that some people give here. I have been eating at this place for over five years now. I live far away from it, but oh may gawd, you must try it. My favorite dish is obviously the Green Chicken Curry with Brown rice, the veggies spring rolls and the mango ANYTHING. I hope i said enough to convince u to at least try it, if u are a curry connoisseur you will know the quality of this magnificent dish. I couldnt think of a better life simple pleasure that enjoying a bowl of green chicken curry from this place. Priceless.
author: Terry R.

description: I came here about an hour before closing with a friend and the waitress was so attentive I felt bad about not making up my mind for 20 minutes.  They didn't try to rush us out, despite us staying until closing.  +1 service.  Lychee martini, despite my disdain for vodka lately.  They didn't have lychee juice, so what was I to do?  Order it with vodka!  It was strong.  +1.  Something not quite right about the food.  I ordered something like garlic pork with lychee I think.  I thought it was good, but not great.  I preferred my friend's fried rice, but I didn't care for the chicken-that-tasted-like-fish part of his order.
author: T. O.

description: Siam Lotus is where it's at. Let me break it down for you: no-frills, but with a pleasant environment. Friendly wait staff and fast service. A meal that won't break your bank. I've never had a bad dish at Siam Lotus, which is why it gets the coveted five stars in my book-that says a lot being that I eat there at least twice a week.
author: louise z.

description: Lots (I meant LOTS) of veg options. The peanut sauce is devine with tofu, the salad that comes with the lunch special has the best dressing. The rice is never stale or dry, The staff is nice and it is very clean! I hate the lunch to dinner break, it has made me have to find other places to go during the off hours.
author: kendy p.

description: I love this place.  I would have given it 4 stars but the last time I went the waitress sucked!  She practically ignored us and it actually took her 15 minutes to give us our bill and the place was empty!  Usually there is a very nice waitress with short curly hair who is excellent.  She gives great suggestions and wonderful service.  The food is flavorful and the prices are reasonable.  I would suggest their basil leaf chicken and their soups. Yummy Yummy!
author: Shani H.

description: Okay, so I've never dined-in.  I can't testify to the quality of the service, although I can say that the 2,376 times I've walked through the dining room on the way to pick up my order I have noticed that the ambience is somewhat bare-bones.  But, hey, it's the Haight.  What do you expect (unless you're at the Alembic--different story)?  Anyway, the food is consistently good; this is one of my local defaults.  And they remember my name when they see me, which is a bonus.
author: Chad W.

description: This is my favorite thai food place. Not just because it's close to my place but their dishes always seem fresh. They have specials that most thai places don't have either. I had a great Salmon Curry special last time. Actually my fiance couldn't decide on just two entrees so we got three! We have a special place in our heart for Green Curry (Emerald Curry) so that was another dish we got. The last was Crispy chicken that was amazing! I love the duck sauce and the fried rice it came with had raisins and nuts that were a nice addition. The staff are really friendly too. This place is a must!
author: Caroline F.

description: Incredible quality, staff that is above-and-beyond friendly and accommodating, and good prices. I love this place.
author: S. F.

description: I'd like to give them the benefit of the doubt, that maybe the horrible service I experienced was a freak occurance, but after talking to some friends who've gone here, I'm not sure that's the case.  When I was there this weekend, we had to wait around a half hour just to have water brought to our table!  But once you get past that, the food is very good.
author: Nick B.

description: Do you know the taste of wet paper? Try their spinach noodles.
author: Dario B.

description: Mmm!  The Veggie Param has touched my tastebuds and left its mark forever!  It was one of the most delicious dishes I've ever tasted!  The rich peanut sauce is really piled on thick on this dish.  It comes with steamed (or fried) tofu, carrots, bok choy, cabbage and other greens.  It totally filled me up and left quite an impression!  The Pad-See-Ew (known by some other name on the menu) was also delicious, according to my companions.  The service was pleasant, prompt and courteous.  The place was clean, even in the bathroom.  I think it's a great bargain too.  What's not to love?
author: Heather D.

description:
there's a waiter at this restaurant that speaks with a thick thai lisping accent that is just gayer than a handbag of rainbows.  and he does these hand gestures that make it look like he's dancing.  it's hilarious.

the food is good, the restaurant is generally quite quiet.  i've been here several times, and i'm a fan.  i've seen cheaper places, but it's still reasonable here.
author: Crystal T.

description: Truly one of the best Thai spots in the city and my personal fave. The food is excellent with fresh and authentic SE Asian ingredients giving each dish a unique bright flavor. I lived in Thailand for several months and am often disappointed by the dull dishes many restaurants try to pass off as real Thai cuisine. Siam Lotus delivers every time, great curries, fish dishes, awesome salads, and friendly service. They have brown rice, which is always a nice option, and tons of lunch specials that go beyond the ordinary. I love the eastern thai veggie salad with chilis, mint, and tofu and their green curry is clean and delicious. Great, now I'm hungry.
author: Kylie S.

description: I love eating Thai food, so Siam Lotus is a regular stop for me around dinner time. All of my visits are good and filling. I enjoy visiting this restaurant not only for the good food, but for the friendly atmosphere of the servers. I especially like the Pad Kee Mao Jae (spicy noodles with vegetables) with tofu. Of the Thai restaurants on Haight, this is the one you should visit.
author: Taylor S.

description: This place is sooo good.  Ive been to a lot of thai places and this one i still remember i came here after hours of shopping in the haight and its the perfect place to go to i had the Thai Basil Chicken and it was amazing!  I cant find any other restaurant that matches up to this one.  and of course you have to eat pad thai when you eat thai, you're probably going to get Pad Thai and their Pad thai was great also .
author: Shelley T.

description: I do love me some thai food!!! Mmmmm mmmmmm! I've gorged myself at many a fine thai restaurant, this one had some dishes that delivered like I"ve never seen before or since. I still sit and reminisce on their coconut pad thai from time to time, haven't been out to try it in almost a year. Not certain if the entire menu delivers at this level, but damn, I just loved this dish!
author: BOB r.

description:
I went to this restaurant my first night in SF about 4 years ago and remembered hating it (it was probably the company more than the food). But I went here over the weekend because Ploy Thai across the street was closed... and it was pretty good!
It was pretty standard decent thai food but their menu was huge! I think all of us were a bit baffled. So many veggie options - and unique ones at that. Very exciting. Somehow I decided to order boring old yellow curry. I think I was tempted by the kabocha squash. It was tasty!
I got the golden triangles for appetizer and yum. Great peanut sauce too.
We had to ask for water and the check and my friend complained about too few mushrooms in his mushroom string bean dish but other than that, I think everyone was fairly happy and the staff was super friendly.
I have to admit I still like Ploy Thai better but I would come again... especially if Ploy was closed.
author: Laura V.

description: I found this place to be so-so.  I ordered the spinach noodles with vegetables--really greasy and salty.  I also ordered one of their specials, which was salmon and mango curry.  This tasted pretty good.  I thought it would all be cooked together though.  It was basically a piece of salmon with curry sauce poured over the top, and slices of fresh mango on the side.  Just wan't what I was expecting.  I don't think I'd go back.
author: Kandi K.

description: Quick, delicious, consistent. If you want spicy, they can go there. Also, the employees just seem like good people. The red curry is bomb.
author: Beatrix K.

description: The food was great and the service SUCKED!!!  Are waiters in San Fran on salary?  Because the majority of them that I met didn't seem to give a hoot if I was there or not.  Case in point: Siam Lotus. We sat at the table w/o menus or water for about 25 minutes.  I mean, come on!  The food was divine but I was so angry at the waiters, who ignored my attempts at eye contact repeatedly, that I decided that no matter how good the food was, it isn't worth going back to, unless i read some really kick-ass review of it.  The emerald curry was fantastic, along with the dish my friend had, which consisted of a pineapple spciy curry sauce with prawns.  Just heavenly. Their sangria was good too, but not worth the 45 minute wait to get the drink.
author: Beth G.

description: I actually like this place, which is surprising to me. Their food is spicy enough and just right for my tastebuds to take in. I also love the consistency of their curries; it's like silk in your mouth.
author: Alex Y.

description:
my FAVORITE thai restaurant. 
i love this place and will go & eat there EVERY single time i go home to the bay.  

everything is good.  i stress everything.

things to definitely try:
chicken coconut milk soup (this soup makes you close your eyes and go "mmmmmm.."  (hahaha.. no joke!))
crab cakes
pad thai
chicken and pineapple fried rice..
shitake scallops & prawns..

and the fried banana or sticky rice and mango.. mmmmm..

it's right in the middle of haight so you can't go wrong.  it's not huge.. but not to crowded either. 

after you walk the blocks and blocks of mom & pop shops.. hit up siam lotus..

you won't be disappointed!
author: Joyce O.

description: Definitely stoked on the meal we just ate there! We ordered spring rolls which were quite tasty, the Mango Jungle Curry which our waitress warned was very spicy but wasn't unbearably so and was very unique and flavorful, the pad see ew which was some of the best I've had and a coconut curry dish which had a deliciously spicy flavor. Our waitress was very nice and attentive, and there wasn't a wait to get a table and service was quick. Nice little alternative to Citrus Club across the street without the crowds and the wait! Bill ran us $53 for 1 appetizer, 3 entrees, and 3 beers.
author: Nick H.

description: Watery curry, unappetizing looking peanut sauce, bland calamari... nice presentation.
author: Marty G.

description: I'd eaten here a few years ago and had remembered how much I loved their papaya salad, so I really wanted it again when I was visiting SF. My friend and I grabbed dinner here on a Friday night. We were seated quickly, but probably waited a good 10 minutes to order and get water even. Also, it wasn't overly busy so this was frustrating. I ordered the papaya salad for a starter and the lamb curry. My friend got some sort of spinach noodle dish. Well, the waitress either didn't hear, or understand, or forgot my salad dish because I never got it, the entrees just came right out. Normally, I would have said something, but I decided I'd probably ordered too much food anyway so I didn't bring it up, but it wasn't very impressive that they would forget. The food was very good but since they forgot my order, had to just give 3 stars. Also, you have to purchase rice separately, even with the curry dish.  Overall, good, but they could be more attentive.
author: Jim G.

description: My regular place for casual Thai grub. The won ton wrapped shrimp and angel wings are delicious starters, along with a papaya salad. Solid curries and the basil chicken is grubbin!  The Pad Thai (new age which is saucier then traditional) is probably one of the best if not thee best in San Francisco.  One of my favorite's, which isn't always on the menu is shrimp with glass noodles (goong woon sen) in a clay pot.  You don't see this dish too often and its even harder to find someone that makes it right.  Last but not least, you can't leave this place until you have fried banana ice cream!  The bananas are dipped in batter and fried to perfection.  Glazed with honey and chocolate sauce, mmmmm mmmmm delicious!
author: Peter S.

description: I liked this place. Went there last night and had the Golden Curry (Gang Karee) with chicken and squash. What you do is smush the squash in with the rice and then you get double starch. Yum. We also had the Spinach Imperial (Pad Mee) that was very delish. I esp liked the shitake mushrooms in it. It was perfectly cooked with a slight tinge of burntness that makes it extra yum. The service was serviceable. efficient. bye.
author: sambacat w.

description: the thai ice tea was really good (tho a lot of ice). ordered a spicy veggie rice noodle (nothing special) and crab cakes (good) to share. probably could have gotten better thai food for cheaper. i think i'll try having some thai rice dishes instead of noodle dishes.
author: Helen L.

description: I've been going here at least once a week since I moved to the area 2 years ago. The gals that work there are super friendly and the food is really high quality for the price. They know I either get the Pad See Ew or the Chicken Yellow Curry (both are very tasty). Sometimes if I bring a guest I will get the Thai Basil Beef and the Mangio Jungle Chicken Curry. Yum!
author: Josh G.

description: Siam Lotus is a really clean restaurant and has really nice employees who were always prompt in getting whatever we needed. I got the pad thai with chicken and it wasn't anything special... the chicken was really dry and it had this really watery sauce that made it soup like... it was slightly bland too.
author: Mitchell F.

description: On my never-ending plight to find that divine Thai meal, my hunger brought me to Siam Lotus after yet another Amoeba excursion. The food smelled good, yet unfortunately my meal would not match the aroma. I ordered the coconut soup which, in the words of Droopy, was "wary, wary bad." More like, "Tasteless," which is even worse. I thought I was playing it safe by ordering the yellow curry, and soon found out that no such thing as a safety net exists in this joint. The chefs here have not quite figured out how to thoroughly cook vegetables. There was also this odd aftertaste with every bite....one should not have to ponder what him/her are eating....especially when dining out. I wish this restaurant nothing but  the impending doom it deserves.
author: Kenny G.

description: Siam Lotus was the very first restaurant I ate at some years back when I moved here, and was pretty damn good, and still continues to please.  Their only drawback is the fact that they don't deliver, but worth it to pick up.  I'm a creature of habit and only ever order Pad Kee Mao, however, when I ask for medium spicy they know how to find that perfect middle range. The pad kee mao is filled with a ton of vegetables, and the right amount of sauce, and somehow they know how to not get the rice noodles to stick together in one big glop like I've had at other places.
author: Jasmine B.

description: The Golden Curry I had here was awesome! As was the Pad See You I tried from my friend's plate. Great food, good prices. Quick service.
author: Gabor C.

description: Best Thai on Haight. Sometimes under-staffed. If you work in the industry you know what to expect from the servers. Polite, and well... Haight Street hospitality. Epic Panang Curry. Check the specials board ya'll! Focus on the food and your company.
author: Mauby N.

description: I love Siam Lotus, this is my second favorite Thai restaurant in the City. (Little Thai, on Polk is my favorite). I really enjoy their calamari, the Chicken in Yellow Curry (although the potatoes aren't always throughly cooked & it's pretty gross eating semi-cooked/semi-raw potatoes), other dishes that have slipped my mind and ALWAYS the Thai Iced Tea. The service is good and the restaurant is pretty spacious. I must say that it's pretty tough trying to enjoy a meal when there are people outside who are hungry and are panhandling for change. Parking is hit or miss, but all of these outside elements one must be prepared for when spending time down in the Haight. Keep up the good work Siam Lotus!
author: Sheila M.

description: I love this place.  Though I miss the old wait staff, and hope for better service these days, the food is good, prices are reasonable.
author: holly e.

description: One of my favorite Thai places in SF.  Great lunch specials and service.  I tend to go for the Spicy Thai Noodles, pumpkin curry with chicken, or spicy eggplant.  I am never disappointed.
author: Jenny S.

description: The food is not the best Thai I've had but is definitely better than mediocre.  The food alone might only merit 3-3.5 stars, but this place earns extra for reasonable prices, friendly and attentive service and beer that was superior in both selection and price -- $2 for a pint of anything on tap: Anchor, Sierra Nevada, Fat Tire, Ranger and others.  I probably wouldn't go out of my way to go again, but would be very happy to return next time I find myself in the area.
author: Liz S.

description: Excellent curry and sticky rice. Tastes just like in Thailand. Wish they had Chang or Leo beer though :0(
author: T M.

description: Everytime I visit the bay area I make sure to stop at Siam Lotus. It's the best Thai place in town NO DOUBT. Food was delicious, service was great and price not too expensive. I would recommend trying everything on the menu as I'm pretty sure it's all good from what I had so far. You should also try the dishes on the chef special menu for something different from the usual. The northern curry egg noodle (kow soi) is a must try!! It's really good and I'm from the northern part of Thailand. The tom yum fried rice is also a must!! The thai tea float is a hidden gem on the menu. If you thought the thai tea was good, the float brings it to a whole other level. I thought the Pad Thai was also very yummy and very similar to what you would find in Thailand. The Pad Thai I've had down here in LA does not compare. The larb tofu was also very satisfying. Now on to the best part DESSERTS!! If you are going to get dessert get the Rotee. Words cannot describe how good this is. You just have to try it for yourself. The mango sticky rice is also good once in a while. However, if you are lucky, they also have dulce de leche cheesecake from time to time. It's one of the best cheesecakes I have ever had, even better than Cheesecake Factory!! So ask for it and you might be in for a real treat :)
author: Justin P.

description: i agree with the other reviewers about the service at this place, however, i am willing to overlook it because the pad thai here is just SO DAMN GOOD.
author: Eileen H.

description: don't even look at the menu, you want the yellow (or golden) curry.  seriously.  best yellow curry i have ever had.  if you don't lick the plate then you probably don't like good food.
author: Alex K.

description: Unfortunately, the food was not that good. I've lived in Thailand for over a month, and maybe I'm spoiled, but that does not mean there are no good Thai Rests. here in the US. The Pad Se Ew  was really dry, pasty, noodles - beef was dry-  not flavorful, and the lime-ade drink was just awful.  The service was so-so, not really like they care if you ever come back.  Such a great location but that might be the only thing going for it.
author: Ron L.

description: i love this place.  the veggie pad thai is different from any other i've had.  it's fresher and the sauce is sweeter.  not better, just different..and a nice segway from usual pad thai.  the vegetables are fresher than any thai i've had in the bay area.  the spring rolls are very fresh too and more peppery.  the restaurant has a really cozy feeling to it too.  lovely.
author: Kate W.

description: wandered here after a day at the academy of science.  i order some curry dish on the lunch menu...  i think it was the first one.   it was ok, i've had better.  the bf order spicy eggplate rice dish with chicken.  His was delicious!  they only have small tables and wooden chairs - no booths so it wasn't very comfy.  good for lunch tho.  service was good.
author: Hello.kitty.kat S.

description: We've been trying to find really decent Thai food in the Haight/Cole Valley area.  Ploy II is our favorite, so far, but it's not open for lunch.  So today we tried Siam Lotus.  We started with the Golden Triangles, which were tasty, but not necessarily divine.  I had a veggie tom kha, while Sweetie had a chicken tom kha.  Mine was clearly the superior soup.  I wasn't crazy about the floating half-mushrooms, which seemed not to have been very cooked.  I like my tom kha with straw mushrooms, not button.  Anyway, moving on, their lunch specials are really reasonably priced.  My shiitake/green bean stirfry with brown rice seemed to be very overly salty, but Sweetie's into that kind of thing, so he didn't see a problem.  He ordered the Thai basil chicken with white rice, and said it was really good.  I like that they use rooibos tea, which always gives a Thai iced tea that characteristic smoky flavor.  The servers were very friendly, and the decor is cute and interesting.  We'll come back for lunch, but I'll probably try something else next time.
author: L. M.

description: Best Thai curry in SF.  The Panang is a great deal - you can have two or three meals for 11 bucks if you order a couple of containers of steamed rice with it.   If you want a quick, delicious, decently priced meal, this is the spot. The staff is really nice, to boot.
author: Karthi X.

description: my favorite thai place in san francisco.  the golden veggie is awesome and they have a great cucumber salad.  i've tried a lot of the dishes there and have never been disappointed.  This is a good place to go when you  are with a group of 3-4.  prices are average for thai in a tourist area, but worth it..
author: Katie Sue A.

description: my king loves the lemon coconut sauce with prawns. it was his first restaurant in SF. he's very pleased.
author: Lady O.

description: I work near Haight Street, and I usually go to Ploy II when I'm craving Thai.  However, the service at Ploy II at lunchtime is seriously spotty, so when I'm in a hurry and need fast, efficient service and decent Thai soup, I come to Siam Lotus.  I always have the Spicy Veggie Rice Noodle Soup, which is tasty and super-filling.  The friendly waitstaff usually give me free refills on soda, and they don't forget that I exist like the young waitstaff working the lunch shift at Ploy II.
author: A W.

description: this is decent thai food, sure, in a city where there's practically one per block. meaning that i don't consider it a destination place: i might not travel out of my hood (where there's thep phanom, thai place II, phucket, chilli cha cha, thai corner express, etc) to eat here, but if you're in the UH, i think it might be better than citrus club or maybe even ploy II. we had veggie spring rolls, pad see ew, and a chicken-veggie rice dish. mine was fine but i saw the coconut pad thai spesh on the way out and wished i'd gotten that. our server was both surly and silent and it wasn't quick by any means but piping hot when it arrived at the table. they were playing KOIT lite rock which was a little bizarre and i think there were some thai hookers sitting next to us (not that it matters) so i felt the ambiance a bit odd but no complaints about the food. it was good, probably better than most typical SF thai places. extensive menu and good veggie options.
author: Mary V.
